name: nytimes
text:
The first wave of the coronavirus outbreak in the U.S. never really ended, and cases are surging again.

But this time, a different and much bigger swath of the country is feeling the effects. https://t.co/hLKgAJJ00i

name: nytimes
text: The first peak of the coronavirus outbreak in the U.S. came at the beginning of April, as 30,000 cases a day were r… https://t.co/w4iyErD8fl

name: nytimes
text:
In parts of the U.S., the coronavirus seemed a distant threat 2 months ago.

But cases have more than tripled in so… https://t.co/uDV2azAOIr

name: nytimes
text:
The shift of the U.S. outbreak means new groups are now experiencing its effects. 

In early April, the New York City area had almost half of all new cases some days. But the current surge has left few counties untouched in much of the South. https://t.co/6T6YbVdqMQ https://t.co/d0X2BK0dqi

name: nytimes
text: Among the areas currently seeing a rapid increase in cases are majority-Hispanic counties along the Southern border, Native American reservations in the Southwest, and majority-Black counties in the Southeast. https://t.co/6T6YbVdqMQ https://t.co/addP0ZbHhq

name: nytimes
text:
The rapid spread of the coronavirus in regions that had previously avoided much of its impact — Arizona, Texas, Florida — has caused some state and local governments to reverse plans to reopen. 

Explore more about the recent surge here. https://t.co/6T6YbVdqMQ

name: nytimes
text: Women like Maya Moore have often been at the forefront — but outside the limelight — as athletes across sports have joined calls for social and racial justice, especially in the most recent wave spurred by deaths of Black people at the hands of the police https://t.co/NgTFij8hIf

name: nytimes
text: In the Covid-19 economy, you can have a kid or a job. Not both. https://t.co/J8haQj65jy

name: nytimes
text: After a barrage of questions and criticism, Florida State University appears to be walking back an announcement that suggested it would not allow employees to care for children while working from home during the coronavirus outbreak https://t.co/otK5LGmS7g

name: nytimes
text: RT @AndrewDasNYT: The NWSL had a helping hand as it worked to save its season this spring: a loan from the government's Paycheck Protection Program that covered team payrolls for eight critical weeks. With @andrewkeh: https://t.co/8gVCiKakXv

name: nytimes
nytimes
text: "They smell blood." Armed men stormed into a drug rehabilitation facility in central Mexico this week, killing 26 men and gravely wounding 5 others, in what the authorities said could be part of a fight over territory between rival criminal organizations. https://t.co/pEq12593Lf

name: nytimes
text: RT @LaurenLeatherby: When the outbreak first peaked in early April, cases were concentrated in a few areas. But it's different during the current surge: It's all over the place. New from @charlie_smart_  and me https://t.co/E9XeoUx9c1 https://t.co/YYH9rYYwdS

name: nytimes
text: By a 5-to-4 vote, the U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday blocked a trial judge’s order that would have made it easier for voters in 3 Alabama counties to use absentee ballots in this month’s primary runoff election https://t.co/TTyBzeNFaY

text: It remains to be seen whether, and how, intelligence showing Russia offered to pay bounties for killing Americans in Afghanistan might affect President Trump’s plans to withdraw from the country, writes @michaelcrowley https://t.co/cPHudBZRLp

text:

name: nytimes
text: "Let me say the quiet part loud: In the Covid-19 economy, you’re allowed only a kid or a job," writes Deb Perelman. "Why isn’t anyone talking about this?" https://t.co/TUfioGUJru

name: nytimes
text: Young lesbians feeling alienated by dating apps and bar culture are finding love on TikTok. “I never thought I would date someone from TikTok,” said an 18-year-old user who met her girlfriend on the app. https://t.co/4qxCuwILGl

name: nytimes
text: Before the word “homosexuality” existed, Karl Heinrich Ulrichs, a lawyer and journalist, argued that same-sex attraction was innate, and that those who experienced it should be treated the same as anyone else https://t.co/c4QWXOpwas

name: nytimes
text: The British pop singer and songwriter Jessie Ware was feeling stalled. A food podcast with her mother showcased her charming personality — and unlocked her creativity. “It’s amazing how it unleashed me.” https://t.co/z97b7dD9fI
